name: RFN-4 "Ion Plasma Sep"
description: The Ion Plasma Sep is the endgame of isotope separation technology: a combined ion-cyclotron resonance (ICR) plasma separator and laser isotope separation (LIS) facility that can achieve high enrichment factors in a single stage — a task requiring hundreds of centrifuge machines at lower tiers. The ICR principle exploits the fact that ions of different mass orbit a magnetic field at different cyclotron frequencies; a resonant RF field applied at exactly one isotope's frequency selectively heats and expels that isotope while leaving others in the plasma cold, producing near-complete isotopic separation in microseconds. The LIS section (based on the SILEX — Separation of Isotopes by Laser EXcitation — process developed in Australia and licensed to GE-Hitachi) selectively photoionizes specific isotopes using tuned laser pulses, allowing electrostatic collection of the target species with isotopic purity approaching 99.99%. Six chambers operate in combination: two ICR separators for heavy fissile isotopes (U-235, Pu-239) and rare fission products, two SILEX chambers for light exotic isotopes (Li-6, He-3, B-10), and two dedicated exotic-element synthesis chambers for precision production of transuranic and rare-earth compounds required for advanced superconductors and high-grade reactor pellets. The 32% feedstock efficiency gain reflects the near-unity separation factor — at this technology level, virtually every target atom in the feedstock is captured and routed to product rather than waste.
